name: Corn Smut
description: A fungal disease affecting maize (corn), caused by Ustilago maydis. It produces large, swollen galls on ears, leaves, stems, and tassels, which later burst and release black, powdery spores, severely reducing crop quality and yield.
symptoms: Large, white/grey swollen galls (tumors) on ears, stalks, leaves, or tassels
Galls darken and burst, releasing black powdery spores

early_stage.description: Appears as small, light-colored swellings or bumps on young corn tissues such as leaves, stems, or ears. These swellings slowly increase in size over time.

middle_stage.description: The swellings grow into large galls filled with black, powdery fungal spores. The outer covering of the gall breaks open and releases spores into the air, which spreads the disease to other plants.

advanced_stage.description: Galls rupture, releasing masses of black soot-like spores (teliospores). The plant tissue is destroyed.

causes: Caused by the fungus Ustilago maydis. The spores can survive in soil and plant waste for a long time. The fungus enters the plant through wounds caused by insects, farming tools, wind damage, or natural openings of the plant.

favorable_conditions.environment: Warm weather, moderate humidity, and injured plants increase the chance of infection. Damage caused by insects, hail, or mechanical work in the field makes it easier for the fungus to enter. Too much nitrogen fertilizer also increases the risk of disease. Drought stress followed by rain can also trigger it.

impact.economic_impact: Reduces grain yield. However, 'Huitlacoche' galls are a delicacy in some cuisines and can be sold at a premium.

prevention: Use disease-resistant corn varieties whenever possible.
Avoid injuring plants during farming activities such as weeding and ploughing.
Control insect pests because they create wounds on the plant.
Remove and destroy infected plant parts and old crop waste after harvesting.
Follow crop rotation and do not grow corn in the same field every year.
Use balanced fertilizer and avoid using too much nitrogen.

chemical_control: There is no direct chemical cure for Corn Smut once the plant is infected. Seed treatments (fungicides) can help protect seedlings but are not effective against later infections.
organic_control: Manual removal of galls before they burst
Neem oil (for insect control to reduce wounds)

resistant_varieties: Some field corn hybrids have resistance. Sweet corn is generally more susceptible.
life_cycle: Teliospores overwinter in soil -> infect young tissue -> form galls -> release spores.
